block.p: At a dinner in the Israeli Embassy in Washington early this year, Yitzhak Rabin took issue with a column of mine opposing the use of U.S. troops on the Golan.

As usual between us, he minced no words, zinging me as being duped and manipulated by press agents for the opposition coalition in Israel. Stung, I responded more vigorously than I would to any other chief of government. The man sitting at the table between us -- Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who never breaches protocol -- blanched at the seeming heatedness of the exchange.

As usual between us, he minced no words, zinging me as being duped and manipulated by press agents for the opposition coalition in Israel. Stung, I responded more vigorously than I would to any other chief of government. The man sitting at the table between us -- Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who never breaches protocol -- blanched at the seeming heatedness of the exchange.
Then the Prime Minister laid his hand on the Secretary's arm and said through the cigarette smoke: "Relax. We can do this because we go back a long way. Let me tell you a story."

He recalled the days he had been Israel's Ambassador in Washington and I was a pro-Israel Nixon speechwriter. Rabin had a special relationship with the President: In the 60's, when Nixon was a nonentity in the political wilderness, he visited Israel and General Rabin showed him the respect that few others did, taking time to point out military defenses in detail.

Nixon did not forget that after his comeback; Rabin was his favorite foreign ambassador. The Israeli made the most of that high regard, and Nixon knew that Rabin would frequently lobby some liberal Jewish Americans on Nixon's behalf.

"There was the time I was sitting in the synagogue on Connecticut Avenue during Yom Kippur," Rabin told Christopher that night. Just before the Kol Nidre service was about to start, he saw this Nixon speechwriter race into synagogue and collapse into his seat near the Ambassador. Out of breath, the Nixon writer told Rabin he had just left the Agnew plane on the 1970 Congressional campaign trail, and made it back just in time.

Then came the rabbi's sermon. To the dismay of both writer and Ambassador, it included a blast at "those who would use alliteration to polarize our society." Rabin commiserated with the Nixon aide and later probably had a few words with the rabbi.

"That's why we can get angry with each other today without getting angry with each other," the Prime Minister told the Secretary 25 years later. I walked out of the Ambassador's residence that night with a good, hot column for my paper and a good, warm feeling for Yitzhak Rabin.
Why did this first Sabra to govern Israel engender such trust in those of us who disagreed with the pace and scope of his West Bank withdrawal?

Because he had been present at the creation of Israel and was as responsible as anyone for its survival; nobody else had such hard-earned credentials. Because Rabin had made a political comeback to win his position fair and square, he earned the right to carry out his policy.

Frankly, it was a grudging faith in Rabin -- in his cool judgment, military experience and absolute integrity -- that kept this pundit from heaping advice on Israelis this year. Not one of his Labor colleagues engenders such trust.

I remember interviewing Rabin in the 70's, during his first prime ministership. It was about midnight; he had just returned to Israel from a trip in Europe but had promised to see me before a deadline and was not one to use exhaustion as a reason to break a promise. His message that night was the urgent need to retain the West Bank for Israel's security; a generation later, he changed his mind and changed his world.

Another memory, shared with millions, is that of his show of exquisite reluctance at the signing ceremony with Yasir Arafat on the White House lawn. The pain of his gamble for peace captured the dissonance torturing Israelis, in contrast to the enthusiasm shown by his rival-partner Shimon Peres.

Some of the Hebrew words spoken by Rabin that day -- part of an ancient prayer -- will be repeated today at his funeral. That is because Jews, in the midst of death and grief, are taught to praise God and celebrate life.
The Jewish people, who go back a long way, have always been inspired by fallen heroes like Yitzhak Rabin to reaffirm their faith.
